acts.title: Act 1 — First Exchange
steps: You arrive to pick up your child, but your ex seems upset.
They start speaking in a confusing or emotional way.
You must choose whether to stay calm, ignore the behavior, or respond emotionally.

acts.title: Act 2 — Escalation
steps: The discussion grows tense, and your ex raises their voice.
Your child notices the tension and becomes unsettled.
Options appear: de-escalate with soothing words, suggest a short break, or argue back.

acts.title: Act 3 — Resolution
steps: Depending on choices, you either reach a small compromise, leave things unresolved, or make the situation worse.
If you stayed calm, your child feels reassured.
If you escalated, the conflict lingers and your child feels stressed.

acts.title: Act 1 — First Date
steps: You decide to meet someone new for coffee.
Your child is staying with your ex.
Do you tell your ex about this date or keep it private?

acts.title: Act 2 — Introducing the Idea
steps: A few weeks later, your child overhears you talking on the phone with the new person.
Your child asks: “Who is that?”
Choices: be honest but gentle, change the subject, or dismiss it quickly.

acts.title: Act 3 — First Reactions
steps: Your ex finds out that you’ve started dating.
They confront you — either calmly, defensively, or angrily.
You can choose to: reassure them that your child’s needs come first, argue, or refuse to discuss.

acts.title: Act 4 — Resolution
steps: Depending on your decisions:
Positive path: Your ex accepts your right to move on, your child feels secure, and boundaries are set.
Neutral path: Tensions remain but are manageable.
Negative path: Conflict worsens, child feels caught in the middle, and co-parenting suffers.
